body:
Overview of osteoarthritis When extensive subchondral cysti c changes are present, calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal
depositi on disease (CPPd) should be considered as well.

header: Osteoarthritis in the footOsteoarthritis in the knee
body:
osteoarthriti s: Standing frontal radiograph of the knee
shows severe carti lage space narrowing, sclerosis, and
osteophytosis of the medial ti biofemoral compartment
(arrows).

header: Degenerative change in the spineErosive osteoarthritis
body:
Overview of erosive osteoarthritis Overview of rheumatoid arthritis The typical changes of o A are only seen in the inferior (synovial) portion of the SI joint.
Erosive osteoarthritis: magnified radiograph
of a digit demonstrates characteristic gullwing appearance of the d IP (yellow arrows).
Boutonnière deformity (PIP fl exion and d IP hyperextension).
Swan neck deformity (PIP hyperextension and d IP fl exion).
Ulnar subluxati on of the fi ngers at the mCPs.

header: Rheumatoid arthritis in the feetRheumatoid arthritis in the hip
body:
Close up of the same image bett er shows
the erosion across the 5th carpometacarpal
joint (red arrow).
Rheumatoid arthritis in the spine Rheumatoid arthritis in the shoulder • Rheumatoid arthritis involves the elbow in approximately one third of patients.
Rheumatoid arthritis with
secondary osteoarthritis: Frontal PA weightbearing
view of the knees shows
cartilage space narrowing
of medial and lateral
tibiofemoral articulations
bilaterally. The lateral
tibiofemoral cartilage
spaces are more markedly
narrowed (yellow arrows).
Prominent osteophytes
laterally (red arrows) signify
secondary osteoarthritis.
Overview of seronegative spondyloarthropathies Sacroiliitis is a hallmark of the spondyloarthropathies Symmetric sacroiliitis: Three patients with ankylosing spondylitis: Romanus and shiny corner lesions: Lateral radiograph of the upper lumbar spine (left image) shows an
erosion of the anterior superior margin of a vertebral body at the discovertebral junction, representing
a Romanus lesion (yellow arrow). The superiorly adjacent vertebral body demonstrates sclerosis of its
anterior inferior margin, representing the shiny corner sign (red arrow). The shiny corner sign signifies
evolution of a prior Romanus lesion.
Bamboo spine: Frontal radiograph of the sacroiliac joints and lumbar spine (middle image)
demonstrates symmetrical sacroiliac joint ankylosis (yellow arrows). There are diffuse syndesmophytes
creating an undulating contour of the spinal column, representing the bamboo spine (red arrows).
There is fusion of the spinous processes, creating the dagger sign (blue arrow).
Cervical fusion: Lateral radiograph of the cervical spine (right image) shows complete ankylosis of the
cervical spine with fusion of the vertebral bodies and facet joints and a pseudarthrosis at C 2–C 3 (green
arrow).
Psoriatic arthritis (arthritis mutilans form): PA radiograph of the hand demonstrates
swelling of the third digit. There are pencilin-cup
erosions of the d IP and PIP joints (red arrows).
multiple joint subluxations produce telescoping
of the digits with a mainen-lorgnette (operaglass hand) deformity.
Case courtesy Barbara Weissman, MD, Brigham
and Women’s Hospital.

header: Jaccoud arthropathySclerodermaPolymyositis and dermatomyositiscrystal deposition arthropathies
body:
Frontal radiograph of
the wrist demonstrates
chondrocalcinosis of the
triangular fibrocartilage
complex (TFCC, arrow),
a common site of
chondrocalcinosis.
Frontal radiograph of
the knee demonstrates
chondrocalcinosis of the
menisci in the same patient.

AP radiograph of the foot shows soft-tissue
swelling surrounding the second mTP. An
erosion of the head of the second metacarpal
features a characteristic overhanging margin
(arrow).
Hemochromatosis: Frontal radiograph of the hand
shows cartilage loss and beaklike osteophytes of
the 1st through 3rd mCPs (arrows).
Case courtesy Stacy Smith, MD, Brigham and
Women’s Hospital.

Hemophilic arthropathy: Lateral
elbow radiograph shows severe
joint space narrowing. Increased
soft-tissue density surrounding
the joint (arrow) is due to
synovial hemosiderin deposition.
In this case, the radial head is
not enlarged, but classically
hemophilia features an enlarged
radial head.
Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), previously called juvenile rheumatoid arthritis PA radiograph of the hand in a
patient with juvenile idiopathic
arthritis shows a shortened 5th
metacarpal (arrow).
Lateral radiograph of
the foot demonstrates
subluxation of the
Lisfranc joint (yellow
arrow). Hypertrophic
degenerative changes
are present at the
tarsometatarsal joint
There was no history of
trauma.
Putting it together: Evaluation of the hands for arthritis: Abc DEs Subluxations Evaluation of bone mineral density Osteophytosis Periosteal new bone
Hand: DIP and PIP Wrist: diffuse (pancarpal) Symmetrical swelling around a joint Asymmetrical swelling around a joint Swelling of an entire digit

Periosteal reaction Very aggressive: Sunburst periosteal reaction Note the associated soft tissue mass (red arrows).
New matrix created by tumor Unique features Central (in the middle of a long bone)

Benign and incidental: Enostosis (bone island) osteoma: Axial
head CT in bone
window shows a
densely sclerotic
osteoma arising
from the cortex
of the frontal
sinus.

T 2-weighted mRI with fat supp.
Conventional osteosarcoma: Radiograph (left image) shows a region of subtle heterogeneous sclerosis
in the medial proximal tibial metaphysis (arrow). No periosteal reaction is apparent, which is unusual
for osteosarcoma. T 1-weighted mRI shows a well-defined region of marrow replacement by tumor
(red arrows). T 2-weighted mRI with fat suppression demonstrates diffuse marrow edema in the tibia,
with a region of decreased T 2 signal (arrow) likely corresponding to the sclerosis seen on radiography.
Benign: Synovial chondromatosis/osteochondromatosis

alignant transformation to chondrosarcoma, with a higher risk in maffucci syndrome.
Frontal radiograph of the foot in a patient
with maffucci syndrome shows numerous
expansile enchondromas most prominently in
the great toe (red arrows). multiple phleboliths
(yellow arrows) represent soft-tissue venous
malformations.
Note the relative paucity of chondroid
calcification, which is typical of the
enchondromas seen in maffucci syndrome.
osteochondroma: Frontal knee radiograph
in a skeletally immature patient shows a
pedunculated exostosis (arrow) of the tibial
metaphysis, with characteristic continuity of
the cortex and communication of the medullary
cavities. The lesion arises from the metaphysis
and projects away from the epiphysis.

Case courtesy Roger Han, MD, Brigham and Women’s Hospital.
Chondrosarcoma: Frontal radiograph of the pelvis (left image) and coronal T 1-weighted mRI (right
image) show an exophytic lesion (arrows) arising from the right iliac crest, which is continuous with the
intramedullary cavity. The lesion demonstrates ring and arc chondroidtype calcification on radiography,
and is heterogeneously hyperintense with a lobulated appearance on T 2-weighted mRI (arrows).
Chondrosarcoma in a different
patient: Frontal and lateral radiographs
of the distal femur show
an intramedullary lesion
with ring and arc chondroid
calcifications. Periosteal
reaction (yellow arrow) and
cortical disruption (red arrow)
suggest aggressive behavior.
Case courtesy Stacy Smith,
MD, Brigham and Women’s
Hospital.

header: Lesions of fibrous originMalignant: Malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH)
body:
other subtypes of chondrosarcoma include the rare mesenchymal and clear cell variants.
A lucent lesion of the right iliac bone (yellow arrows) shows intermediate to hyperintense signal on
protondensity-weighted mRI, with a subtle fluid level (red arrow). The differential diagnosis of a cystic
supraacetabular lesion in a young adult includes cystic fibrous dysplasia and unicameral bone cyst.
Axial CT shows the typical appearance of fibrous
dysplasia of the skull base, with expansile lesions
primarily of the right sphenoid bone that have a
hazy, groundglass matrix (arrows).
FLAIR MRI correlated to the same region
as the CT to the left shows the highly
heterogeneous signal of fibrous dysplasia
(arrows).
Coronal CT and T 1-weighted mRI in the same patient show the true extent of the abnormality
(arrows).
Case courtesy Mary Beth Cunnane, MD, Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary, Boston.

Lateral radiograph of the lumbosacral spine shows
mild loss of height of the L 5 vertebral body with
a subtle lacelike striated trabecular appearance
(arrow).
Axial CT through L 5 demonstrates the typical polkadot sign of the hemangioma, which involves the
complete medullary cavity.

Sagittal CT shows coarsened, vertically oriented
trabeculae with a typical corduroy appearance in
L 5 (arrow).
Sagittal T 2-weighted mRI demonstrates high
signal intensity of the L 5 vertebral body.
(Usually) benign: Giant cell tumor (osteoclastoma) Case courtesy Scott Sheehan, MD, Brigham
and Women’s Hospital, Boston.

Benign: Simple bone cyst (SBC), also called unicameral bone cyst (UBC) Solitary bone cyst: Frontal and lateral radiographs of the proximal tibia in a skeletally immature patient
show a central, expansile lesion of the proximal tibia (yellow arrows). A pathologic fracture is present
with a displaced fragment (red arrows), representing the fallen fragment sign. T 2-weighted mRI with
fat suppression (right image) shows multiple fluid levels (yellow arrows). The differential diagnosis
includes an aneurysmal bone cyst.

Blastic (sclerotic) osseous metastases The main differential diagnosis is
parosteal osteosarcoma; however, the
peripheral ossification more strongly
suggests myositis ossificans. This case was
followed and confirmed by closeinterval
follow-up imaging.

Brown tumor: Axial CT (left image) shows a nonspecific lytic lesion with a faint sclerotic margin
in the left superior pubic ramus (arrow) in a patient with renal osteodystrophy and secondary
hyperparathyroidism. Note the rugger jersey spine on the sagittal CT with alternating bands of sclerosi
(yellow arrows) and relative central lucency (red arrow).
Overview of osteomyelitis Terminology of osteomyelitis

Specific organisms causing osteomyelitis Imaging osteomyelitis Calcaneal osteomyelitis due to foreign body:
Radiograph shows marked thickening of the heel
pad (arrows). No bony changes are evident.
Case courtesy Marie Koch, MD, Brigham and Women’s Hospital, Boston.
Sagittal STIR mRI shows calcaneal bone marrow
edema (red arrow) and a fluid collection (yellow
arrows) within the heel pad, contiguous with the skin.
Coronal T 1-weighted mRI shows the low-signal fluid Sagittal T 1-weighted postcontrast mRI with
collection in the heel pad (yellow arrows), regional fat suppression shows marked enhancement
decreased T 1 marrow signal (red arrow), and (yellow arrows) surrounding the abscess and
irregularity of the calcaneal cortex (blue arrow). enhancement of the surrounding soft tissues.

header: soft-tissue infectionsSeptic arthritisMultifactorial bone diseaseOsteoporosisScurvyOsteomalaciaEndocrine bone diseaseAcromegaly
body:
osteomalacia: Frontal radiograph of the hip
demonstrates an incomplete linear lucency
(arrow) through the medial (weightbearing)
proximal femur, representing a Looser zone.
Case courtesy Stacy Smith, MD, Brigham and
Women’s Hospital.
Hyperparathyroidism: Radiograph of the hand (left image) shows subperiosteal resorption and
scalloping of the radial margins of the 2rd and 3rd proximal and middle phalanges (arrows). Lateral
skull radiograph in a different patient shows the classic saltand-pepper appearance due to trabecular
resorption.

Pseudohypoparathyroidism: Radiograph of
the hand shows a markedly shortened 4th
metacarpal (arrow).

Paget disease of the right
hemipelvis: Frontal radiograph
of the pelvis shows expansion
of the inferior and superior
pubic rami with coarsened
trabecular pattern and cortical
thickening. There is thickening
of both the iliopectineal
(yellow arrow) and ilioischial
(red arrow) lines.
A right total hip replacement
is present, secondary to
pathologic fracture of the
proximal femur. Acetabular
protrusio is present on the
right.

osteopetrosis: Chest radiograph shows dramatic
sclerosis of all the visualized bones in the thorax.

Radiograph of the femur in the same patient
shows a fracture of the proximal femur, status
post o RIF.

Bilateral femoral head avascular necrosis: Frontal pelvic radiograph
in a skeletally immature patient with sickle cell anemia shows
marked flattening and sclerosis of both femoral heads (arrows),
representing advanced (Ficat stage Iv) avascular necrosis.
The Ficat staging of avascular necrosis is subsequently discussed.

Second metatarsal stress fracture: Frontal (left image) and oblique (right image) radiographs of the
foot show a minimally displaced middiaphyseal fracture (arrows) of the second metatarsal. There is
minimal associated callus formation.

header:
Frontal radiograph of the foot shows a
homolateral dislocation at the Lisfranc joint,
with fracture of the base of the second
metatarsal (arrow).
body: the dorsal profile of the tarsometatarsal (Lisfranc) joint should be uninterrupted

Talar osteochondral lesion: Frontal radiograph of the ankle
shows crescentic lucency (arrow)
of the lateral talar dome with
underlying sclerotic change.
Talocalcaneal coalition: Lateral radiograph of the ankle (left image) shows the classic c sign (yellow
arrows) representing the fused medial talus and sustentaculum tali. A fibrous coalition (red arrows)
is confirmed on the coronal CT (right image), with sclerosis and subchondral cysts of the middle
subtalar facet.
The C sign on the lateral radiograph describes a continuous Cshaped contour of the fused middle
subtalar facet (medial talus fused with the sustentaculum tali). The C sign is not sensitive for the
detection of talocalcaneal coalition, but may be helpful when seen.
Medial ankle tendons Anterior extensor tendons along with the posterior tibial tendon* (not drawn), the spring ligament
complex functions to maintain the arch of the foot *most common cause of acquired flat foot is posterior tibial tendon tear
(especially in diabetic patients) posterior tibial tendon (only main component is drawn)
main component inserts on navicular tuberosity and medial cuneiform
plantar component inserts onto bases of 2nd4th metatarsals (not drawn)
recurrent component inserts on sustentaculum tali of calcaneus (not drawn) Weber B (Lauge–Hansen supination–external rotation) ankle fracture:

Pilon fracture: Frontal (left image) and lateral (right image) radiographs of the ankle show
comminuted oblique and vertically oriented fractures (yellow arrows) of the distal tibia with
disruption of the ankle mortise and tibial plafond (red arrow).
Achilles tendon rupture: Lateral radiograph shows a subtle
disruption of the contour of the
Achilles tendon (arrow).
There is also increased soft tissue
and fluid in kager’s fat pad.
kager’s fat pad is a radiolucent
triangle bounded by the flexor
hallucis longus anteriorly, the
calcaneus inferiorly, and the
Achilles tendon posteriorly.

Lateral radiograph of the knee shows a distracted
patellar fracture (arrow), suggestive of an injury
caused by extreme tension of the extensor
mechanism.
Normal anatomy Case courtesy Nehal Shah, MD, Brigham and Women’s Hospital.

Since the cleavage plane is
parallel to the tibial plateau,
the surface of the meniscus
will appear normal.
meniscus myxoid degenerati on: Sagitt al fl uidsensiti ve
mRI demonstrates increased globular signal (arrow) in the
peripheral meniscus that does not extend to the arti cular
surface.
Case courtesy Nehal Shah, MD, Brigham and Women’s
Hospital.
true horizontal tear cleaves the meniscus in a plane parallel
o the tibial plateau. The plane of cleavage appears similar
n both the sagittal (as in the schematic) and coronal views.
ote the associated parameniscal cysts (red arrow).

radial tear of meniscal body Ghost meniscus sign: No meniscal tissue is seen when the plane of
imaging is directly through the radial tear (arrows).
Cases courtesy Nehal Shah, MD, Brigham and Women’s Hospital.
Case courtesy Nehal Shah, MD, Brigham and Women’s Hospital.
Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) Case courtesy Nehal Shah, MD, Brigham and Women’s Hospital.

Normal ACL: Sagittal protondensity (left image) and coronal protondensity fatsat (right image)
mRI shows the normal course of the ACL fibers with the typical striated appearance (blue arrow)
on the sagittal image. The coronal image demonstrates the smaller anteromedial (yellow arrow)
and larger posterolateral (red arrow) fiber bundles in the intercondylar notch.
Secondary findings of ACL tear: Sagittal fluidsensitive mRI image shows bone marrow edema
in the lateral femoral condyle (yellow arrow) and
posterolateral tibial plateau (red arrow), a pattern
characteristic of ACL injury.
Cases courtesy Nehal Shah, MD, Brigham and Women’s Hospital.
Secondary findings of ACL tear in a different
patient: Sagittal protondensity mRI shows
buckling of the PCL (arrow), suggestive of an ACL
injury.
Segond fracture: Frontal
knee radiograph shows an
avulsion fracture of the
lateral tibial plateau (arrow) These fractures can be easily
missed on radiography, but
are important to diagnose.
Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) PCL interstitial tear: Sagittal protondensity
mRI shows a PCL interstitial tear (arrows)
with increased thickness, abnormal signal,
and increased laxity of the PCL.
Cases courtesy Nehal Shah, MD, Brigham and Women’s Hospital.
Case courtesy Nehal Shah, MD, Brigham
and Women’s Hospital.
PCL complete tear (in a different patient): Sagittal
protondensity mRI shows complete rupture of the
PCL with frank discontinuity of the fibers (arrows).
Lateral collateral ligament (LCL) complex Normal anatomy of the extensor mechanism Case courtesy Nehal Shah, MD, Brigham and Women’s Hospital.

Quadriceps tendon tear: Sagittal proton density fatsaturated (left image) and proton density
(right image) mRI shows complete disruption of the distal quadriceps tendon (yellow arrows) with
surrounding marked edema. There is secondary buckling of the patellar tendon (red arrow).
Lateral patellar dislocation: Axial fluidsensitive
mRI demonstrates the typical bone marrow
edema pattern, with contusions of the lateral
femoral condyle (yellow arrow) and medial
patellar facet (red arrow).
The patella has relocated to its anatomic position.
Cases courtesy Nehal Shah, MD, Brigham and Women’s Hospital.

Case courtesy Nehal Shah, MD, Brigham and Women’s Hospital.
Lateral patellar dislocation in a different patient:
Axial protondensity mRI shows persistent lateral
subluxation of the patella, with complete tearing of
the medial retinaculum (yellow arrow).
osgood–Schlatter disease: Sagittal fluidsensitive (left image) and proton density (right image) mRI
shows an enlarged, fragmented tibial tubercle (yellow arrows). There is associated edema anterior to
the tibial tubercle and within Hoffa’s fat pad (red arrow).
Overview and anatomy Pv NS: Lateral knee radiograph shows a dense knee Axial protondensity mRI in the same patient
effusion (red arrows) and a soft-tissue mass posterior shows low signal masses (arrows) posterior to the
to the knee (yellow arrows). knee.
At arthroscopy, multiple synovialbased masses are
evident.
Bony acetabulum Cartilage, labrum, and ligaments A lesser trochanteric fracture in an adult is considered pathologic unti l proven otherwise.

Overview of proximal femur fractures Femoral neck fracture (intracapsular) stage I: Impacted or incomplete femoral neck fracture, with valgus orientati on of the femoral
head/neck trabeculae and varus orientati on of the femoral head and acetabulum. The femoral
shaft is externally rotated. The medial trabeculae of the femoral head and neck form an angle
>180°. This fracture is stable and has a good prognosis.
stage III: Complete, parti ally displaced fracture. There is more marked varus alignment of the
trabecular patt ern of the femoral head and neck, usually forming an angle <160°.
stage IV: Complete, displaced fracture. The trabecular patt ern of the femoral head is aligned with
that of the acetabulum, which is the normal anatomic alignment.
Imaging of metallic hip arthroplasties
Overview and controversy of femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) • Treatment of pincertype FAI is surgical trimming of the acetabular rim.
Three column concept

spinolaminar line: Traces the posterior margin of the spinal canal.
spinous process line: Traces the posterior ti ps of the spinous processes.
The atlantodental interval (Ad I), also known as the atlantoaxial interval, should <2.5 mm in adults.
Lateral cervical spine radiograph shows widening of the Ad I (arrows) to >1 cm, indicati ve of anterior
subluxati on.
Anterior vertebral line: Traces the anterior margin of the vertebral bodies. The prevertebral soft
ti ssues are located anterior to the anterior vertebral line.
Posterior vertebral line: Traces the posterior margin of the vertebral bodies and the anterior margin of
the spinal canal. The spinal canal is the space between the posterior vertebral and spinolaminar lines.

header: Odontoid fractureHangman’s fractureFlexion teardrop fractureExtension teardrop fractureClayshoveler’s fractureBilateral interfacetal dislocation (locked facets)Unilateral interfacetal dislocationGrisel syndrome
body: bony anatomy of the shoulder

header: Posterior glenohumeral dislocationInferior glenohumeral dislocation (luxatio erecta)Os acromialerotator cuff
body:
Imagescourtesy Kirstin Small, MD, Brigham and Women's Hospital Overview of rotator cuff tears Partial articular surface supraspinatus tear: Case courtesy Kirstin M. Small, MD, Brigham
and Women’s Hospital.

Fullthickness rotator cuff tear: Coronal protondensity (left image) and sagittal fatsaturated protondensity (right image) conventional mRI demonstrates complete discontinuity of the supraspinatus
tendon with the tendon retracted proximally (yellow arrow). There is a large effusion, demonstrating
continuity of the glenohumeral joint and the subacromial/subdeltoid bursa (red arrows). Susceptibility
artifact is present in the humeral head, consistent with prior rotator cuff repair.
shoulder ligaments and rotator interval Anatomy of the shoulder ligaments Anatomy of the biceps tendon Biceps tendon subluxation: Coronal (left image) and axial T 1-weighted mR arthrogram with fat
suppression shows medial intraarticular subluxation of the biceps tendon (yellow arrows). The bicipital
groove is empty, best seen on the axial image (red arrow). The blue arrows denote the subscapularis
tendon, seen on the axial image.

Axial T 1-weighted image with fat suppression from
an mR arthrogram shows medial dislocation of the
biceps tendon (yellow arrow) into the subscapularis.
An interstitial tear of the subscapularis tendon is Case courtesy Kirstin M. Small, MD, Brigham and
Women’s Hospital.
Labral normal variants

header: Bankart lesionHill–SachsAnterior labroligamentous periosteal sleeve avulsion (ALPSA)Perthes lesion
body:
Humeral avulsion of the inferior glenohumeral ligament (HAGL) Case courtesy Kirstin M. Small, MD, Brigham and Women’s Hospital.
SLAP tear (type II): Coronal T 1-weighted mR arthrogram with fat suppression shows high signal within
the superior labrum (yellow arrows) extending from anterior to posterior.
Summary of entrapment neuropathies
• Supracondylar fracture is the most common elbow fracture in children.

Essex–Lopresti fracture dislocation: Frontal radiograph of the wrist (left image) shows a probable ulnar
(medial) dislocation of the ulna at the distal radioulnar joint. Although the dislocation is subtle, the ulna
is abnormally rotated as evidenced by the radial displacement of the radial styloid (yellow arrow).

monteggia fracturedislocation: Frontal radiograph of the proximal forearm shows a middiaphyseal ulnar fracture (yellow arrow) and radial head
dislocation (red arrow).

header:
Frontal radiograph of the proximal forearm shows a middiaphyseal ulnar fracture (yellow arrow) and radial head
dislocation (red arrow).
body:
Case courtesy Stacy Smith, MD, Brigham and Women’s
Hospital.
• monteggia fracturedislocation is an ulnar fracture and radial dislocation at the elbow.
galeazzi fracturedislocation: Frontal and lateral radiographs
of the forearm show a radial
diaphyseal fracture of the distal
third of the radial diaphysis
(yellow arrows) and distal ulnar
dislocation (red arrows). The radial
shaft fracture has radial and volar
angulation and foreshortening.
Case courtesy Stacy Smith, MD,
Brigham and Women’s Hospital.
common hand and wrist fractures Carpal anatomy and alignment

Scaphoid fracture: Radiograph
of the wrist shows a minimally
displaced fracture of the scaphoid
(arrow).
Gamekeeper’s thumb (skier’s thumb)

Rolando fracture: PA radiograph of
the hand demonstrates a comminuted
intraarticular fracture at the base of the
thumb metacarpal (arrows).
Boxer’s fracture: PA radiograph of
the hand shows a fracture of the 5th
metacarpal neck (arrow).
volar plate fracture: Lateral radiograph
shows a subtle tiny avulsion fragment
(arrow) of the volar aspect of the middle
phalanx at the PIP joint.
